CAS Key Laboratory of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201210 PR China Controlling product selectivity still remains as a grand challenge for syngas conversion to fuels and chemicals. Herein, ZnO modified CoMn-based catalysts were prepared for direct higher oxygenates synthesis via syngas conversion, and the role of Zn promoter on catalytic behaviour and structure evolution was investigated comprehensively. It was found that the addition of Zn greatly reduced the particle size of active phases including Co and Co2C. Specially, the Zn promoter facilitated the formation of Co2C species, thus effectively tuning the surface ratio of Co/Co2C and strengthening the function for CO associative adsorption and insertion for oxygenates product formation. As a result, the oxygenates selectivity was enhanced to 39.1 wt% over ZnO-promoted CoMn-based catalyst, where more than 96.0 wt% of the produced oxygenates are C2+ products. In addition, Zn promoter can weaken the chain growth ability, leading to the increase of low carbon chain products. Graphical Abstract Zinc oxide promoted CoMn-based catalysts facilitate the formation of Co2C species, thus effectively tuning the ratio of Co2C/Co and strengthening the function for CO associative adsorption and insertion to enhance oxygenates formation. ga1 Keywords Syngas conversion Higher oxygenates synthesis Zinc oxide modified Co/Co2C dual active sites Structure-performance relationship Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Syngas conversion provides an effective platform technology for highly efficient utilization of various non-petroleum carbon resources [1–4], and a series of products such as paraffins [5,6], olefins [7–11], aromatics [12,13] and oxygenates [14–18] can be directly synthesized from syngas conversion. Among which, higher oxygenates (terminal linear α-alcohol and α-aldehyde with two and more carbon number, C2+OH) have promising applications as liquid fuels, fuel additives, intermediates and feedstocks for producing value-added chemicals [19]. Since the discovery of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), various heterogeneous catalytic processes via syngas conversion have been successfully developed [4]. Unfortunately, compared with the industrial FTS reaction process, no commercial catalysts are available for higher oxygenates synthesis (also denoted as higher alcohols synthesis, HAS). The key problem lies in the selective activation of CO molecules on catalyst active sites. The CO activation for higher oxygenates formation includes the dissociative adsorption which favours CO bonds split followed by hydrogenation and coupling to form alkyl species, and the associative adsorption for inserting into the alkyl fragments to generate oxygenates [15,18,20]. Therefore, designing a dual-site structure to coordinate the two types of activation is of great significance for controlling the product selectivity during HAS reaction process. Typically, modified methanol synthesis [21], modified FTS [22], noble metal [23] and Mo-based [24] catalysts are widely applied for HAS reaction. Recently, more and more attention has been focused on modified FTS catalysts for the outstanding catalytic activity, excellent C2+OH selectivity, relatively mild reaction conditions and inexpensive catalyst cost. Particularly, Co/Co2C dual active sites derived from modified Co-based FTS catalysts have attracted increasing attention. Different from the traditional view that Co2C formation is an unfavourable factor leading to the catalyst deactivation during FTS reaction, some previous works [9,14,15,25] have proved that the dual active sites of Co/Co2C can bring dissociative and associative adsorptions of CO bond together, which is necessary to realize both the growth of carbon chain and the insertion of CO bond for HAS reaction. Ding et al. reported CaO-promoted Co/AC catalysts for HAS reaction and found that an appropriate relative ratio of Co/Co2C was beneficial to the synthesis of C1 to C16 alcohols [26]. Liu et al. found that oxygen vacancies boosted Co/Co2C catalysts and a linear correlation between alcohol formation and surface oxygen vacancies was established [27]. Jiang et al. showed that the interface of Co and Co2C efficiently promoted higher alcohols formation [28]. In our previous work, it was found that the ratio of Co/Co2C dual active sites could be regulated by changing the content of Na promoter [25]. The morphology of Co2C nanostructures changed from nano-prisms to nano-spheres, and metallic Co was also observed with the increase of reaction pressure [29]. In addition, it was suggested that the facet of Co2C (111) benefited CO insertion and the formation of Co/Co2C (111) as dual active sites contributed to the enhancement of oxygenates products selectivity. Although lots of work has been carried out on Co/Co2C catalyst systems, it is still necessary to further improve catalytic performance by tuning the detailed structure of Co/Co2C and strengthening the function for CO insertion. Various promoter components play an important role in modulating the performance of FT catalysts [20,30,31]. The addition of metal oxide to the Co-based FT catalysts can modify the support’s texture, Co nanoparticle size and the reduction behaviour of Co species [32]. Alkali and alkaline earth metals have been used in HAS reaction process to increase the amount of Co2+ species and surface basicity, which would enhance oxygenates formation. It was suggested that alkali metals benefit the formation of Co2C for Co-based catalysts [33]. In addition, Zn promoter is always used for CO, CO2 and CH4 activation and it’s also an important component of the classical CuZnAl catalyst for methanol synthesis via syngas conversion [34]. However, the influence mechanism of Zn promoter on the structure-performance relationship is still unclear. Herein, we selected Zn promoter to inhibit hydrocarbon products formation on CoMn-based HAS catalyst and enhance the formation of higher oxygenates as target products. We prepared a series of ZnO-modified CoMn-based catalysts for HAS reaction. Various characterization techniques including X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction spectrum (H2-TPR) and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of adsorbed CO (in situ CO-DRIFTS) were conducted to elucidate the structure-performance relationship of ZnO-promoted CoMn-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts with different Co/Mn/Zn molar ratios (2/1/0, 2/1/1, 2/1/2 and 2/1/4) were prepared by co-precipitation method. Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Mn(NO3)2 (50 wt% aqueous solution), Zn(NO3)2·9H2O and Na2CO3 with analytical grade purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. were used without further purification. Mixed metal salt aqueous solution and Na2CO3 aqueous solution with concentration of 2.0 mol L−1 were added simultaneously into a beaker containing 200 mL deionized water, keeping the speed of solutions stable throughout the dropping process by two peristaltic pumps in order to maintain the pH equal to 8.5 ± 0.1 under continuous stirring. In addition, the temperature was controlled at 30 ± 1 °C. The precursor after titration was aged for 2 h and washed for several times with the deionized water till the pH value of the liquid after centrifugal process was close to 7. After that, the separated solid component was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined in a muffle furnace at 350 °C for 4 h at atmospheric pressure and static air. Finally, the samples were pressed, crushed and sieved to particles in the range of 40–60 mesh. The as-obtained catalysts were denoted as Co2Mn1 and Co2Mn1Znx (x = 1, 2 and 4), respectively. The calcined samples were reduced under flowing atmosphere with 10 vol% H2/N2 (200 mL min−1) for 5 h at 300 °C, and then passivated with 1 vol% O2/Ar (100 mL min−1) for 2 h at room temperature to obtain the reduced catalysts. The spent catalysts were removed from the fix-bed reactor for structure characterization after similar passivation process and separated from the diluent quartz sand. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Powder XRD patterns were obtained with a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation with the wavelength (λ) of 1.54056 Å at 40 kV and 40 mA. The sample was scanned from 30° to 70° continuously at a rate of 4° min−1. The crystallite structure phases were identified by joint committee on powder diffraction standards (JCPDS) standard cards. The average crystallite size was estimated using Scherrer Equation with the strongest diffraction peak. In this work, the relative contents of Co and Co2C species for the spent catalysts were calculated according to the reference intensity ratio (RIR) method. Typically, the strongest peaks of Co and Co2C phases in the XRD patterns were selected and integrated after fitting, the obtained integrated intensities of phases were denoted as I Co and I Co 2C , respectively. The weight percentages were calculated by the following Eqs. (1) and (2). The values of RIR Co and RIR Co 2C were 7.29 and 4.21, which were obtained from the JCPDS standard cards of Co (PDF#89–4307) and Co2C (PDF#65–1457). (1) W Co = I Co RIR Co *( I Co RIR Co + I Co 2 C RIR Co 2 C ) * 100 % (2) W Co 2 C =( 1 - W Co )* 100 % XPS measurements were performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with an Al Kα (hν=1486 eV) radiation source. The XPS spectra were analyzed through the Advantage software, and the binding energies of Co 2p and Zn LM2 photoelectron peaks were corrected by referring to the binding energy of the C 1 s neutral carbon peak at 284.6 eV. (HR)TEM images were obtained from a JEOL-JEM 2011 electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples were prepared by ultrasonic dispersion of the spent catalysts in ethanol followed by adding the suspension dropwise to a carbon-coated copper microgrid for measurement. H2-TPR experiments were carried out to study the reduction behaviour of various samples, using a VDSorb-91i-VAP-HB instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before reduction, about 50 mg calcined sample was loaded into a U-type quartz tube, and purged at 200 °C for 2 h in a 30 mL min−1 Ar flow. After the temperature was dropped to 50 °C and the baseline kept stable, the gas stream was switched to H2. Then the temperature was raised from 50 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, and the reduction curve was recorded continuously. In situ CO-DRIFTS measurements were conducted on a Nicolet iS50 spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) with an MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. Prior to the measurement, the sample was loaded into the DRIFTS cell and pre-treated by heating at 200 °C for 1 h under a 30 mL min−1 Ar flow to remove water and possible impurities species adhered to the sample surface. Subsequently, the cell was cooled down to 50 °C and the background spectrum was recorded. Then, a 30 mL min−1 CO flow was introduced to the cell and the sample spectrum was continuously recorded every 5 min until the sample was completely adsorbed. Lastly, the gas was switched to pure Ar of 30 mL min−1 to flush away physically adsorbed CO, and the spectra were collected with 64 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1 in the range of 4000–900 cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic reaction was carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed plug flow reactor with an 8 mm inner diameter. Typically, 2.0 g catalyst of 40–60 mesh mixed with 4.0 g silica sand of the same particle size was loaded, and the reaction temperature was measured with a K-type thermocouple buried in the catalytic bed. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in situ at 300 °C and atmospheric pressure for 5 h with a heating rate of 1 °C min−1, in a flow of pure H2 with weight hourly space velocities (WHSV) of 3000 mL gcat. −1 h−1. Afterwards, the reactor was cooled down to 200 °C and pressurized to 4.0 MPa in a flow of syngas (H2/CO=2.0, molar ratio, 3.0 vol% of N2 as the internal standard). Lastly, the reaction temperature was raised to 220 °C at a ramping rate of 1 °C min−1 to start the reaction, in a flow of syngas with WHSV of 2000 mL gcat. −1 h−1. The effluent gas, after passing through a hot trap of 120 °C and a cold trap of 0 °C, was analyzed online by an Agilent 7890B gas chromatographer (GC) equipped with two detectors. A TDX-1 carbon molecular sieve column and a TCD with He as carrier gas were used to analyze the H2, N2, CO, CH4 and CO2. The C1–7 hydrocarbons were analyzed by a KCl-modified alumina capillary column (Agilent 19095 P-K25) and a hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID) using Ar as carrier gas. The results were normalized by using CH4 as bridge. The liquid and solid products were collected from the hot trap and cold trap, and then analyzed off-line with three Shimadzu GC instruments, respectively. The aqueous products were analyzed in GC 2014 through two Porapak Q columns equipped with a TCD for H2O and methanol detection and an FID for C1–5 oxygenates detection, the results were normalized by using methanol as bridge. The oil products were analyzed in GC 2010 plus through an HP-1 column with N2 as carrier gas and an FID. The wax was dissolved in CS2 and analyzed in GC 2010 plus by an MXT-1 column with an FID using N2 as carrier gas. The catalytic performance of stabilization on the basis of gas and liquid compositions was typically used for discussion. The mass balance, carbon balance, and oxygen balance were calculated and kept between 95% and 105%. Repeated experiments carried out under the same reaction conditions demonstrated that the studied catalysts show good reproducibility. For a typical reaction performance analysis process, the CO conversion on a carbon basis (C%) was calculated by the following Eq. (3), where CO inlet and CO outlet represent moles of CO at the inlet and the outlet. The selectivity of CO2 (S CO2 , C%) was acquired by Eq. (4), where N i is the molar fraction of product i, and n i is the carbon number of product i. The selectivity on a mass basis (wt%, CO2 free) of product x was obtained by Eq. (5), where x can represent oxygenates (ROH), olefins (RH=), paraffins (RH, including CH4) and CH4. Moreover, S x and m x denoted the selectivity and the mass of product x, respectively. (3) CO conversion = ( CO inlet - CO outlet ) / CO inlet * 100 % (4) S CO 2 = n CO 2 / ∑ ( N i n i ) * 100 % (5) S x = m x / ( m ROH + m RH = + m RH ) * 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure characterization 3.1.1 XRD The XRD patterns of the calcined, reduced and spent CoMn-based catalysts of different Co/Mn/Zn molar ratios are shown in Fig. 1. For the calcined catalysts in Fig. 1a, only Co2MnO4.5 phase (PDF#32–0297) was observed for Co2Mn1 catalyst, which indicated that Co and Mn exist in the form of composite oxide. With the gradual increase of Zn promoter, the phase of Co2ZnO4 (PDF#23–1390) was found. As for Co2Mn1Zn4 catalyst, clear diffraction peaks of ZnO phase (PDF#74–0534) were observed due to the excessive addition of Zn promoter. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 1b. For Co2Mn1 catalyst, both fcc Co (PDF#89–4307) and hcp Co (PDF#05–0727) phases were observed. Besides, MnO phase (PDF#75–0626) was also detected. With the addition of Zn promoter, diffraction peaks of ZnO (PDF#74–0534) were observed, and the peak intensity was in proportion to the amount of Zn promoter. After HAS reaction, the phases of fcc Co (PDF#89–4307) at 2θ of 44.2 and 51.5°, hcp Co (PDF#05–0727) at 2θ of 41.7, 44.8 and 47.6° and Co2C (PDF#65–1457) at 2θ of 41.3, 42.6 and 45.7° were detected, as shown in Fig. 1c. In addition, MnCO3 (PDF#86–0173) phase at 2θ of 31.5, 37.7, 41.6, 45.4, 49.9, 51.7, 60.4, 64.2 and 68.0° was also detected and the Zn species still existed in the form of ZnO (PDF#74–0534) phase. These phases could be clearly observed after enlarging the range of 2θ from 40° to 54° as shown in Fig. 1d. The relative contents of Co2C and metallic Co in the spent catalysts were calculated from the strongest peaks of Co2C and Co phases according to the RIR method (Eqs. (1) and (2)). As shown in Table 1, the ratio of W Co /W Co 2C consistently decreased with the addition of Zn promoter, which indicated that Zn addition could promote the formation of Co2C. In addition, it was evident that the ratio of W Co /W Co 2C can be adjusted by changing the amount of Zn promoter. Furthermore, W Co 2C reached as high as 99.1 wt% for the Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst, which implied that almost all of the metallic Co was converted into Co2C after reactions. Previous studies have proved that Co2C contributes to the formation of oxygenates in HAS reaction [15,25,28]. The average crystallite diameter of Co at 2θ of 44.2° in the reduced catalysts and Co2C at 2θ of 42.6° in the spent catalysts were calculated based on the Scherrer Equation, and the results are listed in Table 1, which indicated that the size of both Co and Co2C nanoparticles decreased with the increase of the Zn promoter. 3.1.2 XPS The effect of Zn promoter on the valence state of the surface elements was investigated by XPS characterization. The XPS spectra of Co 2p and Zn LM2 for calcined and spent catalysts are compiled in Fig. 2. The binding energy of 779.2 and 794.5 eV was associated with Coδ+ (Co2+ or Co3+) while 777.8 eV was attributed to Co0 [25,35]. For the calcined catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2a, the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 peaks for Coδ+ were observed, while additional Co0 peak arose in the Co 2p3/2 orbit for the spent catalysts (Fig. 2b). The relative surface atomic content of the Co species (Co0 and Coδ+) and the atomic ratio of Co0/Coδ+ are listed in Table 2 (Co 2p XPS spectra for Co2Mn1Zn4 catalyst was not obvious due to the excessive ZnO covered on surface). It was clear that, both of the relative surface atomic content of the Co0 and the atomic ratio of Co0/Coδ+ decreased when appropriate amount of Zn promoter was added, which indicated that Zn promoter is conductive to the formation of Co2C on the catalyst surface [31]. In addition, according to the XPS spectra of Zn LM2 (Fig. 2c), the binding energy shifted to the high field direction after reaction, which showed that there existed electronic interaction with electrons losing for Zn species [36]. The electronic interaction may directly determine the valence distribution of Co on the catalyst surface [37]. In addition, the Zn element serving as an electron donor can weaken the adsorption of H2 on the active sites of the catalyst. 3.1.3 (HR)TEM (HR)TEM characterization was employed to identify the microstructure of the spent catalysts ( Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 3a1-a4, Co and Co2C nanoparticles were observed for the spent Co2Mn1 catalyst. Lattice distance of about 2.02 Å was assigned to the hcp Co (002) facet, while lattice fringe of 2.42, 2.18 and 3.12 Å were ascribed to the (101), (020) and (110) planes of Co2C, respectively. Similar (HR)TEM images were obtained for the spent Co2Mn1Zn1 (Fig. 3b1-b4), Co2Mn1Zn2 (Fig. 3c1-c4) and Co2Mn1Zn4 (Fig. 3d1-d4) catalysts. Lattice distance of 1.91, 2.02 and 2.05 Å were corresponded to the hcp Co (101), hcp Co (002) and fcc Co (111) facets, while 2.12, 2.18, 2.42 and 3.12 Å were ascribed to the (111), (020), (101) and (110) facets of Co2C, respectively. The (HR)TEM characterization results further proved that the Co element in the spent catalysts mainly existed in the form of metallic Co and Co2C, which was consistent with the XRD and XPS characterization results. Meanwhile, both Co and Co2C nanoparticles were spherical and the particle size of the spent catalysts decreased significantly as introducing Zn promoter. We collected several TEM images and more than 200 particles were counted through the software of Nano Measurer, and the particle size distribution information was obtained after fitting. The particle size gradually changed from 32.7 to 28.8, 25.9 and 20.8 nm, and the change trend was similar to the results calculated by Scherrer Equation from the XRD patterns (Table 1). 3.1.4 H2-TPR The reduction behaviour of the CoMn-based catalysts was characterized by H2-TPR analysis. As shown in Fig. 4, two distinct H2 consumption peaks were identified for all catalysts. For the Co2Mn1 catalyst, the first peak at 220 °C was attributed to a partial reduction of the CoMn composite oxide (e.g., Co3+ to Co2+, Mn4+ to Mn2+), whereas the second peak around 380 °C originated from the further reduction of the CoMn composite oxide to lower valence (e.g., Co2+ to Co0) [25,33]. With the increase of Zn promoter, the starting-reduction temperature of the first peak shifted towards higher temperature, from 182 to 190, 200 and 208 °C, while temperature corresponding to the first reduction peak rose from 220 to 230, 240 and 250 °C. The starting-reduction and peak temperatures of the second peak followed similar trend. It was found that the existence of ZnO inhibited the reduction of Co oxide species, which may be caused by the decreased reactivity of chemisorbed H2 on catalysts surface or the formation of Co2ZnO4 phase (PDF#23–1390). Due to the weaker reducibility of Zn compared with Co and Mn [38], the formed Co2ZnO4 phase was more difficult to be reduced compared with the Co2MnO4.5 phase (PDF#32–0297), resulting in the increase of the reduction temperature [39,40]. 3.1.5 CO-DRIFTS In situ CO-DRIFTS experiments were conducted to investigate the CO adsorption behaviour for the calcined catalysts ( Fig. 5). Fig. 5a presented in situ CO-DRIFTS spectra of Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst recorded in the process of CO adsorption for 20 min and then purging by Ar for 15 min to remove CO with physisorption (gas-phase CO at 2172 and 2116 cm−1). All of the studied catalysts were treated by the similar process. CO-DRIFTS spectra of the catalysts mainly including CO chemisorption were collected and shown in Fig. 5b. The infrared peaks characterized by vibration at about 1000–1300 cm−1 and 1500–1700 cm−1 were assigned to C-O and CO stretching vibration modes, which suggested the presence of adsorbed carbonates, carboxylates and formates. The formates would probably be located in the vicinity of the Co particles, and they could be considered as potential intermediates in the formation of methanol [41,42]. With the increase of Zn content, the absorption band corresponding to CO stretching vibration (1500–1700 cm−1) clearly moved towards higher wavenumber, which indicated that the feedback electron ability between the catalyst metal component (express in M) and CO was weakened. It seemed that the M-C bond energy became weaker, and the CO bond energy was strengthened [43]. In other words, more associative adsorption was generated to facilitate the insertion of CO bond to synthesize more oxygenates. The phenomenon above was considered to be caused by the electronic effect of Zn promoter. Next, the influence of Zn promoter on the structure-performance relationship was analyzed further based on the evaluation results. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalysts were firstly evaluated under 220 °C and 4.0 MPa, with syngas of H2CO= 2.0 (molar ratio) and WHSV of 2000 mL gCat. −1 h−1. The catalytic performance results are summarized in Table 3 and Fig. 6a. For the Co2Mn1 catalyst, CO conversion reached 33.3 C%. In addition, the selectivity for oxygenates, olefins, paraffins and CH4 was 26.9, 14.5, 58.6 and 27.8 wt%, respectively. When Zn was introduced, although CO conversion decreased, the selectivity of oxygenates was improved. For the case of Co2Mn1Zn1 catalyst, CO conversion decreased from 33.3 to 24.5 C%, while the selectivity of oxygenates significantly increased from 26.9 to 36.8 wt%. Furthering increasing Zn promoter to fabricate Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst, the selectivity of oxygenates increased to 39.1 wt% at CO conversion of 19.7 C%, while the selectivity of olefins, paraffins and CH4 were 30.7, 30.2 and 10.0 wt%, respectively. However, when excessive Zn promoter was added (such as Co2Mn1Zn4 catalyst), CO conversion would sharply decrease to 3.5 C%. Moreover, from the space time yield calculated by unit mass catalyst (denoted as STYROH-catalyst) and unit mass Co (denoted as STYROH-Co) of the target oxygenate products shown in Table S1 and Fig. 6b, the STYROH-catalyst of Co2Mn1 and Co2Mn1Zn2 catalysts remained basically unchanged (27 and 26 mgROH gCat. −1 h−1), but the STYROH-Co increased from 55 to 90 mgROH gCo −1 h−1, which meant that the catalytic efficiency of metal Co per unit mass greatly increased by 64.6%. Meanwhile, the specific products distribution of Co2Mn1 and Co2Mn1Zn2 catalysts is shown in Figs. S1 and S2. The results indicated that RH=/RH (Olefins/Paraffins) ratio of C2 to C18 and Ald./Alc. (Aldehydes/Alcohols) ratio of C2 to C8 increased obviously, which further verified that the addition of Zn promoter weakened the adsorption capacity of H2 and effectively inhibited the further hydrogenation of olefins and aldehydes to produce paraffins and alcohols. As shown in Fig. 6c and d for oxygenates and hydrocarbons distribution, more C1 to C4 oxygenates and C2+ hydrocarbons were acquired with the gradual increase of Zn promoter. For example, the fractions of C5+ oxygenates decreased from 51.5 to 24.8, 31.0 and 1.7 wt%, respectively. In addition, CH4 selectivity changed from 38.0 to 21.0, 16.4 and 30.0 wt%. Fig. 7 plotted oxygenates distribution and chain growth probability of the catalysts. Carbon chain growth factor (α) of oxygenates could be derived from the linear part of the plot and gained by ﬁtting the results generated for chains of two or more carbons using the ASF model. For the Co2Mn1 catalyst, an α value of 0.62 was found and it decreased to 0.53, 0.56, 0.23 for Co2Mn1Zn1, Co2Mn1Zn2 and Co2Mn1Zn4 catalysts, respectively. Besides, as shown in Fig. S3, the α value of hydrocarbons reduced from 0.75 to 0.67, 0.71 and 0.54, which expressed that the distribution of hydrocarbons followed a similar rule as oxygenate products. In brief, the results above suggested that the addition of Zn promoter can weaken the chain growth ability of oxygenates and hydrocarbons for CoMn-based catalyst in HAS reaction process. As the Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst exhibited the highest STYROH-Co, the effect of reaction conditions on catalytic performance of Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst was investigated in detail as shown in Fig. 8 and Tables S4-S6. It can be seen from Fig. 8a that both CO conversion and CO2 selectivity increased significantly with increasing reaction temperature. CO conversion increased from 9.5 to 15.4 C% and the CO2 selectivity from 11.3 to 22.6 C% when reaction temperature was raised from 220 °C to 240 °C. However, the oxygenates selectivity decreased from 43.6 to 32.4 wt%, which indicated that lower reaction temperature was favourable for the formation of oxygenates. As shown in Fig. 8b and Tables S4-S6, although the change of WHSV had no obvious effect on the selectivity of ROH, the selectivity of RH=, Ald./Alc. and RH=/RH ratios decreased significantly when WHSV was reduced from 6000 to 2000 mL gcat. −1 h−1, owing to more secondary hydrogenation caused by longer residence time. Meanwhile, CO conversion and CO2 selectivity increased obviously, from 15.4 to 38.7 C% and 22.6–36.5 C%, respectively. When reaction pressure was reduced from 5.0 to 3.0 MPa, CO conversion decreased from 38.7 to 27.8 C% and the products selectivity remained almost unchanged (Fig. 8c). However, RH= selectivity and RH=/RH ratio increased gradually as reaction pressure was decreased from 5.0 to 3.0 MPa (Table S4 and S6), which showed that olefins were further hydrogenated at higher reaction pressure. As shown in Fig. 8d, when H2/CO molar ratio was changed from 2.0 to 0.5, the CO conversion decreased sharply from 22.0 to 4.8 C%, and CO2 selectivity increased rapidly from 22.0 to 36.7 C%. However, the selectivity of RH=, Ald./Alc. and RH=/RH ratios increased significantly, from 16.7 to 31.5 wt%, 0.4–1.3 and 0.8–2.0 for C2–4 hydrocarbons, respectively. The lower H2/CO molar ratio led to insufficient H2, which hindered the further hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes and olefins to alcohols and paraffins. The catalytic performance of Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst with time on stream for HAS reaction was further investigated as shown in Fig. 9. Over the first 40 h, both CO conversion and product selectivity changed considerably. During this stage, CO conversion and CO2 selectivity increased markedly, and the selectivity of C5++ROH decreased gradually. After about 40 h, the catalytic performance seemed to be stable. At steady state, CO conversion stabilized at about 27.0 C%, the selectivity of CH4, C(2−4)°, C(2−4) =, CO2 and C5++ROH remained at about 4.7, 5.3, 8.6, 23.0 and 58.5 C%, respectively. 3.3 Discussion The Co2C species formation during HAS reaction over the Co-based catalysts and its vital function on the oxygenates synthesis have been discussed in previous works [44–46]. It was suggested that the oxygenates selectivity was closely related to the relative ratio of Co and Co2C [29,47,48]. The formation of the stable Co2C and the interface between the Co and Co2C play a key role in the oxygenates synthesis process [49]. The dual active sites of Co/Co2C can bring dissociative and associative adsorptions of CO bond, which is necessary to realize both the growth of carbon chain and the insertion of CO bond for oxygenates synthesis. The more Co2C phase, the more chances for the CO bond inserting into alkyl species to form oxygenate products. Prior work has associated that alkali metal promoter lowers the barrier for CO dissociation, resulting in carbide formation [50]. The density functional theory (DFT) results also support the more facile formation of Co2C from the Zn/Co catalyst than Co alone [31]. Based on the characterization and performance results above, it could be inferred that the formation of the Co2C and the proper relative ratio of Co/Co2C are the essential condition for HAS over the studied ZnO-promoted CoMn-based catalysts. Zn promoter was attributed to facilitate the formation of Co2C and enhance the oxygenates selectivity. The characterization results from XRD, XPS and (HR)TEM showed that Co and Co2C species coexisted in ZnO-promoted CoMn-based catalyst, and the Zn addition could promote the formation of Co2C. The Co and Co2C particles size calculated by Scherrer Equation (Table 1) or TEM characterization (Fig. 3a1 and b1) decreased due to the introduction of the Zn promoter. In addition, the lower ratio of Co/Co2C also affected the CO adsorption behaviour, which is more conducive to CO associative adsorption for HAS reaction process. The ZnO-promoted Co2Mn1Zn2 catalyst exhibited higher selectivity and STYROH-Co value of the target oxygenates product compared to unpromoted Co2Mn1 catalyst. Moreover, the addition of Zn promoter significantly facilitated oxygenates and olefins formation by suppressing the production of paraffins. In addition, the addition of Zn promoter can weaken the carbon chain growth ability (α value) of oxygenates and hydrocarbons. Co2C typically showed weaker ability for CO dissociation and C-C coupling compared with metallic Co [7,18,30,47], leading to the decrease of α value and shift of product distribution to light components. Meanwhile, due to the existence of Zn promoter, the hydrogenation ability was also weakened on the Co2C surface [18,29], improving the selectivity towards unsaturated aldehydes and olefins. Based on the analysis above, we attempt to give the reaction pathway for HAS process over the ZnO-promoted CoMn-based catalysts as shown in Fig. 10. The metallic Co is the active phase for CO dissociative adsorption and hydrogenation, while Co2C for CO associative adsorption is responsible for the insertion of CO* species. The surface CHx * species are formed on the metallic Co active sites and then CH4 is produced by directly hydrogenation. CH3OH is formed by hydrogenation of molecule adsorbed CO* on the Co2C active sites. The carbon chain growth is propagated through the coupling of CHx * species, forming the CnHz * species, which is then hydrogenated to form hydrocarbons or inserted by molecule CO* to linear aldehydes. Further hydrogenation of aldehydes would result in the alcohols formation. ZnO would promote the formation of Co2C with smaller size. In addition, the weaker hydrogenation and stronger CO associative adsorption caused by ZnO addition also favour the oxygenates formation. 4 Conclusion In this work, the dual-site structure of Co/Co2C and the reaction network for HAS was adjusted by adding Zn into CoMn-based catalyst. The addition of an appropriate amount of Zn reduced the ratio of Co/Co2C significantly by promoting the carburization of Co to Co2C. The total selectivity of oxygenates increased from 26.9 to 39.1 wt%, while the STYROH-Co increased by 64.6%. It was also found that ZnO would favour the production of light products with a decreased chain growth probability. Characterization results suggested that Zn promoter would tailor the phase composition and valence of Co species. Especially, ZnO could weaken the hydrogenation ability and strengthen CO adsorption, which would greatly improve the formation of oxygenates. coredata.dc:description: Controlling product selectivity still remains as a grand challenge for syngas conversion to fuels and chemicals. Herein, ZnO modified CoMn-based catalysts were prepared for direct higher oxygenates synthesis via syngas conversion, and the role of Zn promoter on catalytic behaviour and structure evolution was investigated comprehensively. It was found that the addition of Zn greatly reduced the particle size of active phases including Co and Co2C. Specially, the Zn promoter facilitated the formation of Co2C species, thus effectively tuning the surface ratio of Co/Co2C and strengthening the function for CO associative adsorption and insertion for oxygenates product formation. As a result, the oxygenates selectivity was enhanced to 39.1 wt% over ZnO-promoted CoMn-based catalyst, where more than 96.0 wt% of the produced oxygenates are C2+ products. In addition, Zn promoter can weaken the chain growth ability, leading to the increase of low carbon chain products.
coredata.dc:title: Direct synthesis of higher oxygenates via syngas over zinc oxide modified CoMn-based catalysts
